cards.front: What is the primary function of the **cell membrane**?
cards.back: It acts as a semi-permeable barrier that regulates what enters and leaves the cell to maintain homeostasis.

cards.front: What does the **Fluid Mosaic Model** describe?
cards.back: The cell membrane structure: a flexible layer of lipid molecules (fluid) with large protein molecules embedded in it (mosaic).
The movement of substances across the cell membrane without the use of energy (ATP), moving from high to low concentration.
The net movement of particles from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.
The diffusion of water molecules across a selectively permeable membrane.

cards.front: What happens to a cell in a **hypotonic solution**?
cards.back: Water enters the cell (because the outside has a lower solute concentration), causing the cell to swell or burst.
The movement of materials through a cell membrane using energy (ATP), usually against the concentration gradient (low to high).
Bulk transport processes: Endocytosis brings materials into the cell via vesicles; Exocytosis releases materials out of the cell.
The series of events that cells go through as they grow and divide, consisting of Interphase and M-phase (Mitosis/Cytokinesis).
The cell grows, performs normal functions, and replicates its DNA (S-phase) in preparation for division.

cards.front: Name the four stages of **Mitosis** in order.

cards.back: Chromosomes line up in the middle (equator) of the cell and attach to spindle fibers.
Sister chromatids are pulled apart by spindle fibers toward opposite poles of the cell.
The division of the cytoplasm that results in two separate, identical daughter cells.

cards.front: Why is **Mitosis** important for multicellular organisms?
cards.back: It allows for growth, tissue repair, and asexual reproduction while ensuring each new cell has the same genetic information.
